initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
stories:
A three-year-old girl was rushed to hospital after nearly drowning in a wave pool at a water park on Saturday.

The toddler is in a stable condition following the incident at SplashWorld Water Park at around 14:30 BST on Saturday, authorities said.

A 32-year-old man from Bristol was arrested on suspicion of child cruelty and has been released on bail until 20 August.

Inspector Rachel Patel, of Avon and Somerset Police's Child Protection Unit, said: "Our primary concern is the welfare of the little girl and her family, who are naturally shaken by this ordeal.

"We are working closely with the management of SplashWorld Water Park to piece together what happened and would like to speak to anyone who was in the wave pool area between 13:45 and 14:45.

"I would urge people to refrain from speculating about the incident on social media and to respect the family's privacy at this difficult time."

Police said they are not seeking anyone else in connection with the incident.

In a statement, the water park said: "On Saturday, a young visitor got into difficulty in our wave pool... and our lifeguards responded immediately, providing emergency care until the paramedics arrived.

"We will continue to cooperate fully with the police investigation and review our safety procedures to ensure the well-being of all our guests."

A six-year-old boy was airlifted to hospital after a severe allergic reaction to a snack at a popular amusement park on Sunday.

The child is in a critical but stable condition following the incident at ThrillVille Amusement Park at around 16:00 GMT on Sunday, medical officials said.

A 29-year-old vendor from London was arrested on suspicion of selling contaminated food and has been released pending further investigation.

Detective James Reed, of the Metropolitan Police's Food Safety Unit, said: "Our top priority is the health and safety of the young boy and his family, who are understandably distressed by this incident.

"We are working closely with the management of ThrillVille Amusement Park to determine the cause of the reaction and would like to speak to anyone who purchased food from the vendor between 14:00 and 16:00.

"I would appeal to people to avoid spreading misinformation about the incident on social media and to respect the family's privacy during this challenging time."

Police said they are not ruling out further arrests in connection with the incident.

In a statement, the amusement park said: "On Sunday, one of our guests experienced a severe allergic reaction... and our medical team responded promptly, providing emergency care until the ambulance arrived.

"We will continue to cooperate fully with the police investigation and review our food safety protocols to ensure the well-being of all our visitors."

A three-year-old girl was rushed to the emergency room after ingesting a toxic substance at a children's birthday party at a local play center on Saturday.

The toddler is in serious condition at St. Michael's Hospital, where doctors are working to determine the source of the poisoning, hospital officials said.

A 35-year-old party entertainer from Brooklyn was taken into custody on suspicion of negligence and has been released on bail pending further investigation.

Officer Rachel Martinez, of the NYPD's Child Safety Task Force, urged anyone who attended the party at Playland Playcenter between 10:00 and 12:00 to come forward with any information about the incident.

"We understand that the family is shaken by this event, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything in our power to get to the bottom of what happened," Officer Martinez said.

The play center's management released a statement saying, "We are deeply concerned about the incident and are cooperating fully with the authorities. We will be reviewing our safety procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A five-year-old boy was airlifted to a trauma center after a near-drowning incident at a summer camp in the mountains on Wednesday.

The young camper is in critical condition at Mercy Hospital, where doctors are working to stabilize his vital signs, hospital officials said.

A 28-year-old lifeguard from Denver was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of reckless behavior, camp administrators confirmed.

Sheriff James Reed, of the County Sheriff's Department, urged anyone who witnessed the incident at Camp Clearwater between 2:00 and 4:00 to come forward with any information about the near-tragedy.

"We understand that the family is devastated by this event, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything in our power to determine what went wrong," Sheriff Reed said.

The camp's director released a statement saying, "We are heartbroken about the incident and are cooperating fully with the authorities. We will be re-examining our safety protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A seasoned hiker was medevaced to a remote hospital after a sudden rockslide trapped her on a popular mountain trail on Friday.

The 35-year-old woman, an experienced climber, remains in serious condition at Mountain View Medical Center, where surgeons are working to repair severe leg injuries, hospital officials reported.

A 25-year-old guide from Aspen has been suspended from leading expeditions pending an investigation into claims of negligence, tour company officials confirmed.

Ranger Emily Martinez, of the National Park Service, appealed to anyone who was hiking in the vicinity of Granite Peak between 10:00 and 12:00 to share any information about the rockslide.

"We understand that the hiking community is shocked by this event, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what triggered the rockslide," Ranger Martinez said.

The tour company's owner released a statement saying, "We are deeply saddened by the accident and are cooperating fully with the authorities. We will be reviewing our risk assessment procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A veteran sailor was airlifted to a coastal hospital after a sudden storm surge capsized her yacht on a popular sailing route on Tuesday.

The 40-year-old woman, a seasoned navigator, remains in critical condition at Oceanview Medical Center, where doctors are working to treat severe head and neck injuries, hospital officials reported.

A 30-year-old sailing instructor from Newport has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of recklessness, sailing school officials confirmed.

Coast Guard Commander James Reed appealed to anyone who was sailing in the vicinity of Buoy 12 between 14:00 and 16:00 to share any information about the storm surge.

"We understand that the sailing community is shaken by this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the storm surge," Commander Reed said.

The sailing school's owner released a statement saying, "We are devastated by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our weather forecasting procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A renowned mountaineer was rescued by helicopter from a remote peak after a sudden avalanche swept him off course on a popular climbing route on Saturday.

The 35-year-old man, a seasoned climber, remains in stable condition at Mountainview Hospital, where doctors are treating him for severe leg and back injuries, hospital officials reported.

A 28-year-old guide from Aspen has been suspended pending an investigation into allegations of negligence, expedition company officials confirmed.

Park Ranger Captain Emily Patel urged anyone who was climbing in the vicinity of Peak 14 between 10:00 and 12:00 to share any information about the avalanche.

"We understand that the climbing community is reeling from this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what triggered the avalanche," Captain Patel said.

The expedition company's owner released a statement saying, "We are heartbroken by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our risk assessment procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

The 40-year-old man, a veteran skipper, remains in serious condition at Oceanview Medical Center, where doctors are treating him for severe head and chest injuries, hospital officials reported.

A 32-year-old crew member from Newport has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of recklessness, yacht club officials confirmed.

Coast Guard Commander Rachel Lee urged anyone who was sailing in the vicinity of Buoy 12 between 14:00 and 16:00 to share any information about the storm.

The yacht club's commodore released a statement saying, "We are devastated by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our weather forecasting procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

The 35-year-old woman, a seasoned climber, remains in critical condition at Mountainview Hospital, where doctors are treating her for severe spinal and leg injuries, hospital officials reported.

The climbing federation's president released a statement saying, "We are heartbroken by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our weather forecasting procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

The 40-year-old skipper, a decorated champion, remains in intensive care at Seaside Hospital, where doctors are treating her for severe head and chest injuries, hospital officials reported.

A 32-year-old crew member from Annapolis has been barred from competition pending an investigation into allegations of reckless navigation, sailing federation officials confirmed.

Coast Guard Commander Rachel Lee urged anyone who was sailing in the vicinity of Buoy 12 between 14:00 and 16:00 to come forward with any information about the storm.

The sailing federation's commodore released a statement saying, "We are devastated by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our weather monitoring procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

The 35-year-old climber, a celebrated explorer, remains in stable condition at Base Camp Hospital, where doctors are treating her for severe leg and spinal injuries, expedition officials reported.

A 28-year-old guide from Boulder has been suspended from leading climbs pending an inquiry into allegations of inadequate risk assessment, mountain guides association officials confirmed.

National Park Ranger Mark Thompson appealed to anyone who was climbing in the vicinity of the West Ridge between 08:00 and 10:00 to come forward with any information about the avalanche.

The mountain guides association's president released a statement saying, "We are heartbroken by the accident and are fully collaborating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our weather forecasting protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A veteran deep-sea diver was winched to safety from the dark depths of the Pacific Ocean by a rescue submersible after a catastrophic equipment failure plunged her research vessel into darkness during a record-breaking dive on Tuesday.

The 40-year-old marine biologist, a leading expert in her field, remains in critical condition at a coastal hospital, where doctors are treating her for severe decompression sickness and nitrogen narcosis, rescue officials reported.

A 32-year-old engineer from the vessel's maintenance team has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of neglecting safety checks and ignoring warning signs of equipment malfunction, coast guard officials confirmed.

Rescue Mission Commander, Rachel Lee, urged anyone who was sailing in the vicinity of the research vessel between 08:00 and 10:00 to come forward with any information about the unusual ocean currents.

"We understand that the scientific community is reeling from this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the equipment failure to occur with such catastrophic consequences," Lee said.

The oceanographic institute's director released a statement saying, "We are deeply distressed by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our maintenance procedures and safety protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A renowned storm chaser was airlifted to safety from the eye of a category 5 hurricane by a search and rescue helicopter after a devastating instrument failure crippled her team's vehicle during a daring expedition on Wednesday.

The 35-year-old meteorologist, a pioneer in extreme weather research, remains in stable condition at a nearby medical center, where doctors are treating her for severe injuries and exposure to the elements, emergency officials reported.

A 29-year-old technician from the team's support crew has been suspended pending an inquiry into allegations of disregarding safety protocols and neglecting to perform crucial checks on the vehicle's instruments, authorities confirmed.

Rescue Operation Chief, Mark Thompson, appealed to anyone who was in the vicinity of the storm chasers' vehicle between 14:00 and 16:00 to come forward with any information about the unusual storm patterns.

"We understand that the scientific community is shocked by this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the instrument failure to occur with such devastating consequences," Thompson said.

The severe weather research center's director released a statement saying, "We are deeply troubled by the accident and are fully cooperating with the authorities. We will be reviewing our safety procedures and maintenance protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A celebrated deep-sea explorer was dramatically rescued from the wreckage of her submersible vessel by a naval salvage team after a catastrophic systems failure stranded her on the ocean floor during a groundbreaking expedition to the Mariana Trench on Friday.

The 40-year-old marine biologist, a leading authority on abyssal ecosystems, is recovering in a Honolulu hospital, where doctors are treating her for decompression sickness and injuries sustained during the harrowing rescue operation, naval officials reported.

A 32-year-old engineer from the research team's support staff has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of bypassing safety protocols and failing to conduct critical inspections on the submersible's life support systems, authorities confirmed.

Rear Admiral James Reed, commander of the naval salvage operation, urged anyone who was in the vicinity of the submersible's dive site between 08:00 and 10:00 to come forward with any information about the unusual ocean currents that may have contributed to the accident.

"We understand that the scientific community is shaken by this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the systems failure to occur with such disastrous consequences," Reed said.

The oceanographic institute's director released a statement saying, "We are deeply disturbed by the accident and are fully cooperating with the naval authorities. We will be reviewing our safety procedures and maintenance protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A renowned astrophysicist was miraculously saved from the crippled space station by a heroic team of cosmonauts after a catastrophic malfunction left her stranded in Earth's orbit during a historic mission to study a rare celestial event on Wednesday.

The 35-year-old expert on black hole physics, a pioneer in her field, is recuperating at a Moscow hospital, where doctors are treating her for radiation exposure and injuries sustained during the perilous rescue operation, space agency officials reported.

A 29-year-old mission controller has been suspended pending an inquiry into allegations of neglecting critical system checks and overriding safety warnings on the space station's life support systems, authorities confirmed.

Cosmonaut General Viktor Petrov, commander of the rescue mission, appealed to anyone who was in contact with the space station's crew during the fateful hours to come forward with any information about the unusual solar flare activity that may have contributed to the malfunction.

"We understand that the scientific community is reeling from this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the catastrophic failure to occur with such devastating consequences," Petrov said.

The space agency's director released a statement saying, "We are deeply disturbed by the accident and are fully cooperating with the cosmonaut corps. We will be reviewing our safety protocols and maintenance procedures to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

A decorated oceanographer was dramatically rescued from a crippled deep-sea submersible by a brave team of navy divers after a disastrous equipment failure left him trapped on the ocean floor during a groundbreaking expedition to explore a recently discovered underwater volcano on Friday.

The 40-year-old expert on marine geology, a leading authority in his field, is recovering at a San Diego hospital, where doctors are treating him for decompression sickness and injuries sustained during the treacherous rescue operation, naval officials reported.

A 32-year-old engineer has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into allegations of disregarding critical safety protocols and bypassing warning systems on the submersible's life support systems, authorities confirmed.

The naval academy's superintendent released a statement saying, "We are deeply troubled by the accident and are fully cooperating with the navy's board of inquiry. We will be reviewing our safety procedures and maintenance protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."

The 38-year-old expert on cosmic radiation, a pioneer in her field, is recovering at a Houston hospital, where doctors are treating her for radiation exposure and injuries sustained during the perilous rescue operation, NASA officials reported.

NASA Administrator, Dr. Maria Hernandez, urged anyone who was in contact with the station's crew during the fateful hours to come forward with any information about the unusual solar activity that may have contributed to the equipment failure.

"We understand that the scientific community is shaken by this incident, and we want to assure them that we are doing everything possible to determine what caused the catastrophic failure to occur with such devastating consequences," Hernandez said.

The space agency's director released a statement saying, "We are deeply disturbed by the accident and are fully cooperating with the NASA's review board. We will be reviewing our safety procedures and maintenance protocols to prevent anything like this from happening again in the future."
